The purpose of the Miss N.D. Scholarship Organization is to recognize potential, reward achievement and to provide scholarship dollars to encourage N.D. women to continue their educations. Area delegates include Ryli Kuhnhenn of Rugby, crowned Miss Magic City, and Gabriella Lilley of Belcourt, crowned Miss Turtle Mountain. The Rugby track and field team showed up at the 2024 NDHSAA State Meet with one goal in mind: winning the whole thing. Both boys and girls arrived in Bismarck on the back of a successful season. There was success to come as the Rugby girls finished eighth overall in Class B with 26 points ... December 14, 1920-May 21, 2024 Park River Dorothy M. Axvig, age 103 of Park River and formerly Rugby, ND passed away on Tuesday, May 21, 2024 at the Good Samaritan Center of Park River, with her loving family by her side. Dorothy Marie (Ingulsrud) Axvig was born December 14, 1920 in ... L. Jay Reinke, Rugby Two huge thanks are due two entities in Rugby. First, the Public Works/Roads Dept. staff and drivers deserve a massive thanks for the great job they have done with snow removal and road maintenance during our recent storms. It’s a huge feat, and you have done it ... Pierce County May 14 Whitley Raquel Arredon Adam, 35, Williston, driving under suspension (Class B misdemeanor) 10 days in the Heart of America Correctional and Treatment Center, six days suspended, community service in lieu of jail, $275 in court fines and fees. Michael L. Axelson, 57, ... Copyright © The Pierce County Tribune | https://www.thepiercecountytribune.com | 219 South Main Ave., Rugby, ND 58368 | 701-857-1900'}]

human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': "Stay up-to-date on the latest in local and national government and political topics with our newsletter. The North Dakota Industrial Commission on Monday awarded more than $15 million for three projects aimed at reducing environmental impacts and increasing energy efficiency. The three-member board approved the proposals from the Clean Sustainable Energy Authority, which has held three grant rounds since its inception after the 2021 legislative session, totaling awards of $250 million in loans, $20 million in hydrogen grants from federal dollars and $24.3 million in state grants. No more grant rounds will be held until additional funding has been approved by the Legislature. The new grants include $10 million for engineering and design work on the “Liberty H2 Hub” project, an effort led by the University of North Dakota's Energy and Environmental Research Center to develop large-scale facilities for low-carbon hydrogen development. A grant of $4.2 million was awarded for “Project Phoenix,” a proposal submitted by a California-based company called Newlight Technologies, which wants to manufacture biodegradable plastic using methane as a feedstock. Denver-based Enerplus Corp. is getting $1.1 million for geothermal power generation for oil and gas production. “The three projects funded today will leverage $5 million in state dollars and $10 million in federal dollars to unlock over $19.5 million in private investments into North Dakota’s energy future,” the Industrial Commission said in a joint statement. The commission is made up of Gov. Doug Burgum, Attorney General Drew Wrigley and Agriculture Commissioner Doug Goehring. Reach Jackie Jahfetson at 701-250-8252 or jackie.jahfetson@bismarcktribune.com. Stay up-to-date on the latest in local and national government and political topics with our newsletter. Energy and Environment Reporter Get up-to-the-minute news sent straight to your device."}]

[{'sentences': [{'generated_prob': 0.0004740672302432358, 'sentence': "Saturday, June 1, 2024 By Cecile Wehrman The North Dakota Dem-NPL party chair calls it “outrageous and baffling.” No matter what you call it, the decision not to independently investigate the erasure of the email account of North Dakota's late attorney general is just plain wrong.", 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 0.0006230329163372517, 'sentence': "That this decision comes from the agency charged with making sure other units of government adequately comply with open records laws is unseemly and gives a pass to a staff member who actually put in writing her desire to shield the attorney general's emails from future public records requests.", 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 0.0009282167302444577, 'sentence': "That's a clear statement of motivation to circumvent North Dakota's open records law.", 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 0.0008450319292023778, 'sentence': "Liz Brocker, longtime executive assistant to Wayne Stenehjem, was concerned, according to an email to the state's IT department, “especially as he kept EVERYTHING.” I would expect no less of Stenehjem, who was a champion of open records.", 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 0.0005241498583927751, 'sentence': "It's a shame his legacy will now be entangled with suspicion, however unwarranted.", 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 0.0005867025465704501, 'sentence': "Coming from the woman who fielded media requests for opinions from the attorney general ᅳ many related to open records ᅳ it's laughable to ascribe no ill intent to her actions, as current Attorney General Drew Wrigley did last week.", 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 0.0006826450116932392, 'sentence': 'Brocker, who is not an attorney, is nonetheless well-acquainted with the law, making her actions even more egregious.', 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 0.0006897369166836143, 'sentence': "An investigation would also answer why the state's IT department would comply with her request.", 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 0.0008101110579445958, 'sentence': "Notwithstanding that there is apparently no specific policy or law about retention of state emails, Brocker's motives for deleting the account were clearly aimed at an end run around laws she dealt with everyday.", 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 0.0009035683469846845, 'sentence': "It should 0.0008920548134483397, 'sentence': "Far from protecting Stenehjem's legacy, she has opened a chasm for speculation on what that email account may have contained.", 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 0.0007543488754890859, 'sentence': "Beyond that, she's destroyed the words of a well-loved and capable public servant.", 'perplexity': 0, 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 0.0009497948922216892, 'sentence': "Beyond any potential scandal or conspiracy fodder, Brocker has deleted Stenehjem's wit, logic and musings on 'highlight_sentence_for_ai': False}, {'generated_prob': 0.0013679265975952148, 'sentence': "Words reach across time and bring to life who we were when we wrote them, making them all the more precious the text is written entirely by a human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'Saturday, June 1, 2024 By Cecile Wehrman The North Dakota Dem-NPL party chair calls it “outrageous and baffling.” No matter what you call it, the decision not to independently investigate the erasure of the email account of North Dakota’s late attorney general is just plain wrong. That this decision comes from the agency charged with making sure other units of government adequately comply with open records laws is unseemly and gives a pass to a staff member who actually put in writing her desire to shield the attorney general’s emails from future public records requests. That’s a clear statement of motivation to circumvent North Dakota’s open records law. Liz Brocker, longtime executive assistant to Wayne Stenehjem, was concerned, according to an email to the state’s IT department, “especially as he kept EVERYTHING.” I would expect no less of Stenehjem, who was a champion of open records. It’s a shame his legacy will now be entangled with suspicion, however unwarranted. Coming from the woman who fielded media requests for opinions from the attorney general — many related to open records — it’s laughable to ascribe no ill intent to her actions, as current Attorney General Drew Wrigley did last week. Brocker, who is not an attorney, is nonetheless well-acquainted with the law, making her actions even more egregious. An investigation would also answer why the state’s IT department would comply with her request. Notwithstanding that there is apparently no specific policy or law about retention of state emails, Brocker’s motives for deleting the account were clearly aimed at an end run around laws she dealt with everyday. It should go without saying that the people charged with upholding the public’s right to know are not entitled to special treatment. Far from protecting Stenehjem’s legacy, she has opened a chasm for speculation on what that email account may have contained. Beyond that, she’s destroyed the words of a well-loved and capable public servant. Beyond any potential scandal or conspiracy fodder, Brocker has deleted Stenehjem’s wit, logic and musings on myriad topics, the breadth of which I can only imagine knowing the amount of material any of us who sit in front of a computer all day share via email with colleagues and friends. Words reach across time and bring to life who we were when we wrote them, making them all the more precious once we’re gone. In the case of a private person, those words may mean little to the public. For a public figure who served in state government for decades the value of Stenehjem’s words are potentially huge. It’s not for Liz Brocker or anyone else to decide what becomes of a public servant’s work product. It belongs to us — the people. That’s the covenant public servants make when they run for election. Their work is no longer entirely their own. Nor should their emails be. Secret Service texts Believing that Liz Brocker had no nefarious intention save to protect Wayne Stenehjem’s legacy is a lot like swallowing the idea Secret Service texts from Jan. 5 and 6, 2021 were innocently deleted in a data “migration.” Now, much like the vacuum created by the deletion of Stenehjem’s email account, the inability to retrieve those records is creating potentially more speculation than the texts themselves may have warranted. Again, we’ll probably never know. As I watched Thursday night’s Jan. 6 committee hearing, I came away convinced that a smoking gun as to Donald Trump’s actions in the presidential SUV were less likely to be found than incredibly personal messages sent to family and friends by agents protecting Vice President Mike Pence at the Capitol. Much like Brocker’s professed desire to protect her late boss, it’s understandable that someone at the Secret Service felt justified in trying to shield Pence’s detail from having personal messages become public. But again, the loss to history in understanding that Secret Service agents feared for their lives — not to mention our contemporary understanding of these events — are irreparably harmed when very human expressions are destroyed. Laws aimed at protecting the public’s right to know and the right of news outlets to publish such information are enshrined in law precisely to take human sentiment and emotion out of the equation. Democracy cannot thrive in darkness, obfuscation, nor however well-intentioned, attempts at shielding someone’s privacy. If you work in the government or have been elected to office you have explicitly agreed to a loss of some privacies. The American people must never accept any other standard. No matter what you call it, the decision not to independently investigate the erasure of the email account of North Dakota’s late attorney general is just plain wrong. That this decision comes from the agency charged with making sure other units of government adequately comply with open records laws is unseemly and gives a pass to a staff member who actually put in writing her desire to shield the attorney general’s emails from future public records requests. That’s a clear statement of motivation to circumvent North Dakota’s open records law. Liz Brocker, longtime executive assistant to Wayne Stenehjem, was concerned, according to an email to the state’s IT department, “especially as he kept EVERYTHING.” I would expect no less of Stenehjem, who was a champion of open records. It’s a shame his legacy will now be entangled with suspicion, however unwarranted. Coming from the woman who fielded media requests for opinions from the attorney general — many related to open records — it’s laughable to ascribe no ill intent to her actions, as current Attorney General Drew Wrigley did last week. Brocker, who is not an attorney, is nonetheless well-acquainted with the law, making her actions even more egregious. An investigation would also answer why the state’s IT department would comply with her request. Notwithstanding that there is apparently no specific policy or law about retention of state emails, Brocker’s motives for deleting the account were clearly aimed at an end run around laws she dealt with everyday. 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'Saturday, June 1, 2024 Angeline Kachena Angeline Kachena Angeline Kachena, 87, Park River, died Friday, Jan. 19, 2018, at Lutheran Sunset Home of Grafton. Services were held today, Wednesday, Jan. 24, at St. Mary’s Catholic Church of Park River, with burial at Calvary Cemetery, Park River. Tollefson Funeral Home of Park River was in charge of arrangements. Angeline A. Hodny, daughter of Joseph J. and Mary V. (Drtina) Hodny, was born June 5, 1930, in rural Lankin. She attended rural school near Bechyne and worked on the family farm. She married Frank C. Kachena on June 21, 1949, at Bechyne. The couple made their home in Grafton and Park River. She worked at Borden’s Potato Plant, ran Angie’s Café and worked at Welch’s Café and Friendship. She retired and cared for her son Frank. She continued to make her home in Park River until the time of her death. She was a member of St. Mary’s Catholic Church. She is survived by her children: Pat (Len) Novak, Fallbrook, California, Debbie (Steve) Fontaine and Greg Kachena, both of Park River, Laurie Loeffler and Linda (Steve) Onstad, both of Grand Forks, Ron (Deb) Kachena, Yankton, South Dakota, Teresa (David) Erickson and Jenny ( Tim) McDonald, both of Grafton; 22 grandchildren; numerous great-grandchildren; and sister, Marian Mayer, Grand Forks. She was preceded in death by her husband on April 10, 1978; son, Frank J.; daughter, Connie; two great-grandchildren; sister, Delores Novak; and brother, Leonard Hodny. But look at it from Biden’s perspective or, more precisely, look at the politics from Biden’s perspective. President Barack Obama ordered all of the American troops out of Iraq. He did so over the objection of practically his entire defense and national security team including the secretary of state, secretary of defense, the national security adviser, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the U.S. ambassador to Iraq and the CIA director. Outgoing President George W. Bush expected the new president to leave a stay-behind force. But Obama called Iraq “a dumb war” and ordered the troops home. The pullout, as Bush predicted, created a vacuum. Enter the Islamic State group. In response, Obama gradually sent back to Iraq about the same number of troops that Bush considered necessary. Some, mostly Republicans who were maligned as warmongering “neocons,” criticized what they denounced as the Obama “bug-out.” But, politically, Obama did not suffer. How many Iraqis died because of his reckless, premature pullout? Few ask, even fewer care. In April 2003, according to Gallup, approval for the war in Iraq, which began less than two years after 9/11, reached 76%. Sens. Hillary Clinton and Joe Biden voted for the war. Even liberals like The New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman supported it. But, over time, approval declined. Clinton apologized for her vote. Some Democrats and their media comrades believed “Bush lied; people died.” Former Associated Press D.C. Bureau Chief Ron Fournier claimed that “Bush lied us into the war in Iraq.” Even presidential candidate Donald Trump said: “They lied. They said there were weapons of mass destruction. There were none. And they knew there were none.” Never mind that Laurence Silberman of the bipartisan Robb-Silberman Commission, formed by Bush to examine the intelligence behind the Iraq war, wrote: “No one in Washington political circles offered significant disagreement with the intelligence community before the invasion. The National Intelligence Estimate was persuasive — to the president, to Congress and to the media.” Americans forgot, or stopped caring, that Saddam Hussein, after the Gulf war of 1990-1991, promised — but failed — to declare what WMD he had. He threatened America; was stealing from the Oil-For-Food Program; was shooting at the British and American planes patrolling the no-fly zone over the Kurdish areas; had used chemical weapons on the Iranians and on his own people; had attempted to assassinate President George Herbert Walker Bush and had invaded Kuwait. Human Rights Watch estimates that more than 250,000 Iraqis were eliminated by Saddam. The war in Afghanistan began with wide support. The Taliban allowed al-Qaida to use the country to plan the deadliest terror attack on American soil in history, a tragedy that cost nearly 3,000 lives. But public support waned — even though, before President Trump withdrew more than 2,000 troops, our military commitment in Iraq dropped to 5,200 troops. Trump, and many Republicans and Democrats, complained about “endless wars,” disregarding endless enemies who never get the memo. Even the bipartisan criticism of Biden’s disastrous pullout from Afghanistan centers more on how he withdrew the troops, not that he did so. In three weeks, Russia has reportedly lost more troops in Ukraine than America did in Iraq and Afghanistan combined in 20 years. Yet Iraq and Afghanistan are routinely called mistaken misadventures in “nation building” that we were goaded into by “neocons.” A 2021 AP-NORC poll found that 62% of Americans say the war in Afghanistan was “not worth fighting,” and 63% say the same thing about the war in Iraq. American public opinion initially supports war, even the Vietnam War. But approval morphs into not only opposition, but into questioning the “true motive” for engaging in war. Given this history, Biden’s reluctance to “do more” for Ukraine becomes understandable. To find out more about Larry Elder, or become an “Elderado,” visit www.LarryElder.com.
